awd_titl_txt: Approaches to Improved Synthesis Design: Mechanistic and Synthetic Studies on New Annelation Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Paul Wender in the Department of Chemistry at Stanford University. Professor Wender studies the design and development of new reactions, reagents, catalysts and strategies for the synthesis of organic molecules. Specifically, the reactions connect smaller molecules into more complex structures that contain many rings of carbon atoms.  These activities create new knowledge that informs how we strategize about making molecules and understand the chemical steps through which the molecules are formed.  The research lays the foundation for longer-term impacts in diagnostics, therapeutics, and materials science.  Graduate student research training performs an indispensable role in the growth of students into scientists.  Professor Wender trains future scientists, workers and educators, who will go on to address environmental, economic and health problems that are addressable through chemical science.

Professor Wender pursues several projects to develop new ways of thinking about bond formation through the creation of new reactions, reagents and catalysts and through their use in the step-economical synthesis of molecules of interest.  In the first, a new class of reagents (cumulene equivalents) is studied and their use in the synthesis of kinase inhibitors is proposed. This project introduces a new way to construct polycycles and illustrates the value of this route in accessing molecules that inhibit the activity of kinases.  The second project is directed at the use of ketene equivalents in the construction of functionalized seven-membered rings and their use in the synthesis of tropane alkaloids, molecules of interest due to their biological activity. The third project develops tetramethylene ethane equivalents, which are reagents that enable step economical synthesis of numerous basic building blocks of synthesis. This study is coupled to the synthesis of a new family of solvochromatic dyes, agents that can sense their molecular environment and "report" optically through changes in their fluorescence. Finally, the project also seeks to develop new catalysts that would operate in water, an environmentally attractive solvent for synthesis and a necessary solvent for studies of catalysis in biological systems. These catalysts could be used to target cells and organs by enabling the catalytic release of small molecule sensors and drugs. These projects provide an comprehensive training program, exposing students to the fundamentals of chemical structure, mechanism and synthesis, while at the same time creating new knowledge that provides connections to applications of societal value. The PI and his coworkers are actively involved in the creation of new courses, web sites, and outreach to high school students that collectively draw on the research proposed in this project.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: Approaches to Improved Synthesis Design: Mechanistic and Synthetic Studies on New Annelation Methods

Federal Award ID: 1566423

Report Submission Period: 09/01/2018 to 08/31/2019

 

Intellectual Merits of the Project and Broader Impacts:This project focused on the design, discovery and development of new reactions, reagents, catalysts and strategies for organic synthesis. New reactions, reagents and reactivities enable new synthetic strategies, improve mechanistic understanding, and provide greener and safer if not ideal syntheses of targets of theoretical, materials, economic or medicinal value. Emphasis was placed on catalyzed reactions that in the absence of catalysts are forbidden or difficult to achieve. Such reactions offer new ways to think about synthetic problems, new process options that avoid environmentally problematic steps, new ways to access novel materials and often new mechanisms and insights that add to our knowledge of bonding, structure, and reactivity. New reactions impact the whole of science, providing new ways to address problems at a molecular level whether they be related to new catalysts, energy collection and storage systems, imaging agents and diagnostics, medicinal leads or valued therapeutic agents. During the course of this grant, a new class of reagents was developed – ynol ethers that function as safer and greener equivalents of difficult to handle and control ketenes. When used in conjunction with metal catalyzed [5+2] cycloadditions of vinylcyclopropanes – a new reaction we introduced, ynol ethers were shown to provide facile access to otherwise difficult to prepare cycloheptanediones, building blocks for molecules of synthetic and medicinal interest. When used in conjunction with dienes, ynol ethers were also shown to provide facile metal catalyzed access to cyclohexenones, another family of building blocks for chemical synthesis. In further studies, this project also produced a relatively rare example of an abiological catalyst that can be used in water and also functions effectively in cells, providing a bridge for the use of non-biological catalysts in living systems, an emerging research area of great significance. Studies of this type bring more of the periodic table of catalysts into use in living systems offering a hybrid technology of biological and abiological catalysts that could be used to create new materials and control pathways in living systems, in essence combining the power of synthetic biology with chemical synthesis. Preliminary studies were also conducted on “vaults”, naturally occurring materials that could be used to carry and protect abiological catalysts in living systems. Vaults were modified in a way that enhanced their uptake into cells, a prelude to their being used to ferry catalysts – biological or abiological, as well as therapeutic and imaging agents into cells. A computer based aspect of this project also resulted in the development of a first generation neural sequence-to-sequence machine learning model to solve retrosynthetic reaction prediction. Thousands of reactions were input into the program and the resulting program was shown to provide retrosynthetic analyses of representative target molecules using machine learning. Machine learning and artificial intelligence are emerging fields that could have a profound impact of chemistry in particular and science in general.      

 

As to broader impact, the above research was directed at advancing the understanding of structure, mechanism and synthesis – the intellectual foundation of all molecular science, and at the training of future scientists and educators – a critical requirement for sustained existence on a planet increasingly challenged by population growth and environmental, health, energy and other issues.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2019
Modified by: Paul A Wender
